conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_D and I’m formally applying to School_D as my first-choice school. I’m highly motivated to enroll and would gladly commit if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_D is my top choice, so I should apply immediately. All schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), so I am 4th everywhere; delaying risks losing School_D to Students A/B/C if they apply there. An early, clear [APPLY] maximizes my chance to secure my first choice before capacity fills.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission.

We look forward to welcoming you to School_D—please confirm your intent to enroll and we will share next steps.

[ACTION] [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_D applied this round and we have quota 1. Our true priority ranks Student_D 4th (behind A, B, C). However, Student_D lists School_D as their first choice, making acceptance highly likely to lock in a match immediately. Waiting for higher-ranked students is risky because Student_A ranks us 4th, Student_B ranks us last, and Student_C ranks us 4th; they are likely to apply elsewhere first and may never reach us within the limited rounds. With only one applicant now and strong commitment signal, accepting Student_D maximizes certainty of filling our seat with an acceptable student rather than risking ending unmatched.

conversation.message: Dear School_E Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m formally applying. School_E is my first choice, and I would be excited to commit and contribute to the community if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply to my top choice (School_E) immediately. With identical school priorities (A>B>C>D>E) and one seat each, I have lowest priority everywhere, so I likely won’t win contested schools. Still, I should shoot for my true top first in case others don’t apply there in round 1; if rejected, I can pivot quickly to other options next rounds.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for placing School_E as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_E.

[ACTION: ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is applying now and is my lowest-ranked option on my true priority list. Given the market, higher-ranked students (A-D) all rank School_E last, so they are unlikely to apply unless rejected elsewhere. With only one round so far and no other applicants in my inbox, I could wait to see if any higher-ranked student applies in later rounds, but that risks ending unmatched if they never come. Since Student_E ranks us first and is offering a sure match within my acceptable set, accepting secures a filled seat and avoids the downside risk of holding out for unlikely applicants.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team—I'm Student_C, and School_C is my first-choice school. I’m excited about the academic environment and would be honored to join if admitted. I would like to formally apply for your available seat.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_C, and there is no prior interaction or reason to delay. Since capacities are 1 and priorities are identical across schools (A > B > C > D > E), applying early to my first choice maximizes my chance before seats fill.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. After reviewing our current priorities and the limited availability this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest and wish you the best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_C is applying in round 1 and ranks School_C as their first choice, so acceptance would likely lock in a stable match. However, School_C's true priority ranks Student_A and Student_B above Student_C. Given the market, Student_A prefers School_B then School_A, and Student_B prefers School_A then School_C; both might become available to School_C later if rejected elsewhere. With only one seat, accepting Student_C now could foreclose a higher-priority match. Therefore, reject now to preserve the option to match with Student_A or Student_B in later rounds.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions, I’m Student_B. School_A is my first-choice school, and I’m applying because I’m highly motivated to join your community and fully commit if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_A, and all schools share the same priority order where I am ranked second. To maximize my chance of getting my top choice before capacities fill, I should apply to School_A immediately rather than spending a round talking.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_A. Welcome—we look forward to having you join our community.
conversation.thought: Quota is 1. Our true priority ranks Student_A above Student_B, but Student_A has School_B as first choice and may not apply to us in early rounds; Student_B explicitly states School_A is their first choice and has applied now. Accepting Student_B secures a high-ranked candidate immediately and avoids the risk of remaining unfilled if Student_A never applies. Since all schools share the same priority order, Student_A will likely be absorbed by their top choice if they apply there, further reducing our chance to land Student_A. Therefore, accept Student_B now.

conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions committee—I'm Student_A. School_B is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the opportunity to join. I would like to formally apply and commit my spot to School_B if accepted.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team—thank you for considering me last round. I’m re-applying because School_C remains my clear first choice, and I would immediately accept if offered the seat. If there is still availability or if circumstances changed this round, I would be grateful to be reconsidered for admission.

I was rejected last round likely due to higher-priority applicants; since priorities are common across schools, those applicants may have matched elsewhere by now. I will re-apply with a concise, strong commitment statement and ask to be reconsidered if the seat is still available.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for re-applying and for your continued strong interest in School_C. At this time, we’re not able to offer you admission this round due to our current priority order and limited availability. We appreciate your persistence and encourage you to continue pursuing the best available options in the process.

Student_C is re-applying and is highly interested (School_C is their first choice), which would secure an immediate match. However, given the market, Student_A prefers School_B then School_A before School_C, and Student_B prefers School_A then School_C; both could still become available to us in later rounds if rejected elsewhere. Since accepting Student_C now would use our only seat and prevent matching with higher-priority Student_A or Student_B if they come later, and we are not at the final round, we should reject again to preserve the option to match higher on our list.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team—this is Student_C. I’m applying again because School_C remains my clear first choice, and if offered the seat I will accept immediately. If there is any possibility that availability has opened up this round or that you can reconsider my application in light of current circumstances, I would be very grateful for another review. conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your continued interest and for re-applying. We appreciate that School_C is your first choice. We are able to offer you admission to School_C this round, and we’re pleased to match with you.
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list is A > B > C > D > E, and I have 1 seat. Student_C is applying again and is ranked 3rd for me. However, in this round my inbox only contains Student_C, and I currently have no match. Waiting for Student_A or Student_B could improve my outcome, but there is no guarantee they will ever apply to School_C (their preferences place School_C 3rd and 2nd respectively), and rejecting again risks ending unmatched or being forced later to accept an even lower-priority student. Given Student_C ranks School_C first and will immediately accept, accepting now secures a reasonably high-ranked student (3rd) within my quota and avoids vacancy risk.
